You are a code expert. Please use your professional knowledge to generate accurate and professional responses. Who is the Bull King

"Who is the Bull King" is a simple and fun card game suitable for 2-10 players. The game consists of 104 cards, each with numbers from 1 to 104, and each card features a different number of bull heads. This game has won multiple awards, including the 1994 German Players' Award and the 1996 Best Mind Game Award.

## Game Rules

**Dealing**: Each player receives 10 cards, with 4 cards placed face-up on the table as the initial tableau. Excess cards are discarded.

**Playing**: At the beginning of each round, each player selects one card from their hand to play face-down.

**Card Placement Order**: When all players have placed their cards face-down, the system automatically reveals and places the cards, starting with the card closest in value to the last card on the tableau. If cards are equally close, the smaller card is placed first.

**Placement Rules**: Cards are preferentially placed in positions that don't require collecting cards, then in positions closest to the end card on the tableau, and finally in positions where the end card has a smaller value.

**Card Collection**: When a player places a card that is smaller than the last card on the tableau, or when placing a card in the sixth position, they must collect all the previous cards and their played card becomes the new first card on the tableau.

**Game End**: There are two ways to end the game, chosen by players: either when all cards from players' hands have been played, or when a player reaches 66 bull heads.

## Card Quantities
If there are fewer than 10 players, reduce the deck size by 20 cards for every 4 fewer players. For 7-10 players, use cards 1-104; for 3-6 players, use cards 1-84; for 2 players, use cards 1-64.

checklist.title: Is the basic card game structure properly implemented?
checklist.description: Assess whether the code correctly implements the 'Who is the Bull King' game structure with proper card distribution (104 cards with bull heads) and dynamic deck sizing based on player count. Check if the code properly assigns bull head values to each card and handles the initial tableau setup with 4 face-up cards. Score 0 if the card system is missing, 5 if cards are implemented but have incorrect bull head assignments, and 10 if the full card system with proper scaling for player count is implemented correctly.

checklist.title: Is the card placement logic implemented according to the rules?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code correctly implements the specific card placement order rules: placing cards closest in value to the last tableau card, handling equal-distance cases by prioritizing smaller cards, and following the described placement hierarchy. Deduct 5 points if the placement logic doesn't handle edge cases (like equal distances), 3 points if the ordering is incorrect, and 5 points if the placement hierarchy is missing. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the card collection mechanism correctly implemented?
checklist.description: Check if the code properly enforces the rule where players must collect all cards when placing a card smaller than the last tableau card or when placing a sixth card. Verify that collected cards are properly accounted for in bull head scoring and that the played card correctly becomes the new first card in the tableau. Deduct 5 points if collection rules are partially implemented, and 10 points if completely missing. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Are the game end conditions properly implemented?
checklist.description: Verify that the code implements both game-ending conditions: either when all cards from players' hands have been played, or when a player reaches 66 bull heads. Check whether the code allows players to choose between these options at game setup. Deduct 5 points if only one ending condition is implemented, and 3 points if the player choice mechanism is missing. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the code robust?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the code can handle common abnormal situations (such as out-of-bounds input, network interruption, user operation errors, etc.) and provide friendly error prompts or recovery mechanisms. Code with strong robustness should be able to effectively handle these edge cases, giving 10 points. If the robustness is average, give 5 points, and if no exceptions are handled, give 0 points.

checklist.title: Are there any innovative features that are eye-catching?
checklist.description: Check whether the code includes surprise features that enhance the experience (e.g., 1. Card animation effects during placement 2. Historical statistics tracking for players 3. Interactive tutorials for new players). Add 3 points for each practical innovative feature implemented (maximum 10 points).

checklist.title: Are there any redundant features?
checklist.description: Strictly check three types of redundancy: 1. Redundant implementation of similar functions (e.g., multiple card selection logics coexisting) 2. Function modules unrelated to the Bull King game (e.g., a built-in mini-game) 3. Fancy effects that affect performance (e.g., excessive card animations). Deduct 3 points for each redundancy found, and directly deduct 10 points if the core functions are interfered with by redundant code.

checklist.title: Does the code have engineering quality?
checklist.description: Review modular design (such as separating game logic/view/network layers), unit test coverage, and build process automation. Deduct 5 points if global state pollution is found or design patterns are not used; deduct 5 points if the code duplication rate is too high (over 30%); deduct 5 points if the build process is not automated. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Does the interface vision meet professional design standards?
checklist.description: Evaluate whether the overall design follows modern design principles: 1) Harmonious color matching (no more than 3 primary colors) 2) Proper layout spacing (element spacing follows the 8px multiple principle) 3) Professional font system (body font size ≥ 14px, line height over 1.5 times). Deduct 3 points for each crowded visual element, 5 points for a glaring color combination, and 5 points for chaotic text-image layout. The full score is 10 points.

checklist.title: Is the dynamic interaction smooth and seamless?
checklist.description: Judge whether the dynamic effects conform to human perception characteristics: 1) Click feedback delay ≤ 100ms 2) Transition animation duration controlled between 300-500ms 3) Clear visual focus guidance for card selection and placement. Deduct 5 points for each operation without feedback, 3 points for visual after-images during card movement, and 5 points for hard-to-find key function buttons. The full score is 10 points.
